SUPPLY BILL


    Order for Second and Third Readings read.

2.32 p.m.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance (Mr Tang See Chim) (for the Minister for Finance): Mr Speaker,

Column: 785

Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    The Main Estimates of Revenue and Expenditure for the financial year 1st January, 1969, to 31st March, 1970, have been considered and approved by the House as Cmd. Paper 27 of 1968. Under section 85 of the Constitution of Singapore, heads of expenditure other than statutory expenditure to be met from the Consolidated Fund have to be included in a Bill to be known as the Supply Bill. The purpose of such a Bill is to provide for the issue from the Consolidated Fund of the sums necessary to meet the expenditure and the appropriation of these sums for the purposes specified therein.

    The Supply Bill before Members is to give legislative approval for the issue of funds from the Consolidated Fund to meet the sums of expenditure for the financial year 1st January, 1969, to 31st March, 1970. In the Schedule to the Bill are shown the various heads of expenditure and the sums that may be incurred in respect of each head. These have been approved by the House in the Estimates of Expenditure for the financial year 1st January, 1969, to 31st March, 1970, and appear in pages 53 and 54 of Cmd. Paper 27 of 1968.

    Once the Supply Bill is approved, the Minister for Finance will be empowered to issue warrants authorising expenditure up to the amount under each head as shown in the Bill to be paid out from the Consolidated Fund.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Question put, and agreed to.

    Bill accordingly read a Second time.
Third Reading


    Mr Speaker: Mr Tang, will you please move the Third Reading?

    Mr Tang See Chim: Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Third time."

    Question put, and agreed to.

    Bill accordingly read a Third time and passed.

NATIONAL MUSEUM
(AMENDMENT) BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

    The Minister for Science and Technology (Dr Toh Chin Chye): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    The purpose of this Bill is to legislate for the formation of a Museum Board. Members of this board will be drawn from the public. The purpose of this board is to advise the Director of the Museum on the setting up of exhibits in the museum and generally to make the museum attractive so that visitors to the museum will find it a pleasure to do so. Members of this board will be drawn not only from those connected with education but also generally from people who find that using the museum is instructive and educational.

Column: 788

STAMP (AMENDMENT) BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

2.44 p.m.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance (Mr Tang See Chim) (for the Minister for Finance): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    Members will recollect that in the Budget Speech the Minister for Finance mentioned that the rates of stamp duty for a number of items, most of which have not been revised since the 1930s, would be revised to bring them in line with the present value of money and to suit present day conditions. From the revenue angle, the most important item of stamp duty is on conveyances on property, accounting for 40 per cent of the stamp revenue during 1966. The existing rate is $2 for every $100 or part thereof. It is proposed to base the duty on a sliding scale. Where the value of the property is up to $30,000, there will be no change in the existing rate and, as such, purchasers of Housing and Development Board flats or other low-cost houses will not have to pay higher stamp fees. Where the value of the property is above $30,000, and not more

Column: 789

than $50,000, there will be an increase of 50 cents for every $100 or part thereof on the value of the property exceeding $30,000. In respect of property exceeding $50,000, there will be an increase of $1 for every $100 or part thereof on the value of property exceeding $50,000. It is quite reasonable that purchasers of property of higher value pay more.

    At present the rate of duty on the transfer of shares and stocks is 15 cents for every $100 or part thereof where the name of the transferee is filled prior to the execution of the transfer, in other cases, the rate is 20 cents for every $100 or part thereof. It is proposed to increase the stamp duty to 20 cents and 30 cents respectively.

    The present fee of 10 cents per share certificate will be increased to $1 for every $1,000 or part thereof of the par value in respect of new share certificates. This revised rate will also apply to certificates issued in respect of bonus and rights issues. The higher fee is justified because, in subsequent transactions, very often shares change hands without registration, resulting in a loss of revenue. At the same time, the existing flat rate of 50 cents on a contract note will be replaced by an ad valorem duty. A duty of $1 for every $1,000 of the value of the shares and stocks will be payable.

    The stamp duty on cheques will be raised from 10 cents to 15 cents and on receipts from six cents to 10 cents.

    Apart from these, there are small increases in the rate of stamp duties on mortgages, leases, insurance, appraisements, etc.

    There is, however, no increase in the duties on 15 items. These consist of the following five items for which there has been no increase in the rates since 1935.

    (i) bonds on superannuation annuity - the rate is 25 cents for every $100;

    (ii) bonds of any other kind whatsoever - the rate is $5;

    (iii) apprenticeship deed - the rate is $1;

Column: 790



    (iv) policy of sea insurance, where the premium does not exceed $1 - the rate is five cents; and

    (v) life insurance policy for every $1,000 insured - the rate is 10 cents per $1,000 or part thereof.

    The first two items affect people in the lower income group and item (iii) affects students who wish to learn a trade. In the case of item (iv) , if a higher duty is charged, it may divert business to other countries as the policy of sea insurance could be taken elsewhere. In the case of life insurance policy, the rate is not increased because there is an automatic increase in the amount of stamp duty payable with the larger value of life policies being taken now.

    The ten items for which the rates have not been increased since 1952 are as follows:

    (i) affidavits and statutory declarations - $2;

    (ii) bonds on letters of administration where the estate does not exceed $10,000 - $2;

    (iii) power or letter of attorney for appointing a proxy or where the value of a property is below $1,000 - $1;

    (iv) any instrument certified or endorsed by a public notary - $2;

    (v) reconveyancing of mortgaged properties and securities:

    (a) where the amount of monies secured does not exceed $1,000 - $1;

    (b) where the amount of monies secured is between $1,000 and $10,000 - $3;

    In any other case, the rate is $10;

    (vi) declaration of any trust or instrument chargeable with duty on a settlement - $10;

    (vii) appointment of a trustee - $10;

Column: 791



    (viii) duplicate of any instrument chargeable with duty - $2;

    (ix) protest of bill or note made by a public notary attesting the dishonour of a bill of exchange or promissory note - $1; and

    (x) revocation of any trust of any property other than a will - $10.

    The specific rates of duties affect generally people in the lower income group. Affidavits and statutory declarations are required by people for purposes of identity cards, birth certificates and for admission of children to schools, etc. In the case of bonds on letters of administration, the specific duty is only applicable for release of estates of less than $10,000. This will affect families with small means. Power or letter of attorney appointing a proxy to vote at a meeting is a very small item of revenue.

    In the case of the other items, the present rates are reasonable, considering that the parties affected would have to pay duties on the other instruments connected with the transactions.

    Members will note that where the items affect people in the lower income group, the duties will remain unaltered and, at such, the revision of stamp duties will only affect people who can afford the small increases in the rates.

    Clause 2 of the Bill seeks to amend section 36 (1) of the Stamp Ordinance by increasing the flat fee for adjudication from $1 to $25 to cover the cost of services performed by the Commissioner of Stamps. In addition, it is proposed to introduce a fee where the value of the property has to be certified by .1 Government valuer. This fee will be based on the difference between the amount declared by the applicant and the amount certified by the Government valuer as follows:

    (a) a fee of one per cent will be charged on the first difference of $10,000;

Column: 792



    (b) a fee of half per cent will be charged on the next difference of $90,000.

    Where the difference is in excess of $100,000, the rate of duty will be one-quarter per cent. This measure is necessary to circumvent and discourage under-valuation by applicants.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Question put, and agreed to.

    Bill accordingly read a Second time and committed to a Committee of the whole House.

    The House immediately resolved itself into a Committee on the Bill. -[Mr Tang See Chim].

    Bill considered in Committee; reported without amendment; read a Third time and passed.

Column: 792

STATUTORY BOARDS (TAXABLE SERVICES) BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

2.55 p.m.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance (Mr Tang See Chim) (for the Minister for Finance): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    Sir, before I deal with the Bill which covers two of the four new taxes announced by the Minister for Finance in his Budget Speech, I would like to say that the response of the public to the additional tax measures is heartening. These tax measures have been described as mild and fair because the new taxation has been kept to the minimum and the additional burden is spread thinly over a large number of persons who are able to pay without being over burdened.

    Some Members have expressed fears that the levy on Public Utilities Board bills will cause hardship to the poor households. In fact, the levy is based on the ability to pay and the burden on the lower income group is minimal. This has been achieved by avoiding any additional tax on cheaper cooking fuels and by exempting households whose

Column: 793

P.U.B. bills do not exceed $10 a month. There is a rough relationship between the amount of the P.U.B. bill and the economic status of the household. The very poor are not on the P.U.B. billing list or have bills between $1 and $5. Such households use only little electricity for lighting and consume little water. The next group with P.U.B. bills between $6 and $10 consumes more electricity and water. There are some 58,000 households, or roughly 25 per cent, whose monthly P.U.B. bills are less than $10. These people do not have to pay tax on their bills. As the income rises, households purchase refrigerators, radios, television sets and install fans, water-heaters and air-conditioners. The average monthly cost of power for each of these appliances is as follows: 

                                       Average

          Article                   cost of power

                                      per month

                            

          Fan                         $3 to  $4

          Refrigerator                $3 to  $4

          Television                  $3 to  $4

          Water-heater                $5 to  $6

          Air-conditioner

            (one horse-power unit)   $27 to $30


    It is also possible to isolate the really poor households y the type of cooking fuel used, suhc as kerosene, charcoal and wood. Sir, may I rfer to teh Singapore Sample Household Survey, 1966, which was conducted by the Ministry of National Development and the Economic Research Centre, University of Singapore? It is entitled Singapore Sample Household Survey, 1966, No 1, and printed by the Government Printer in September 1967. The table I refer to, Sir, is H.54 at page 234 of the Report. According to this survey, of the total 331,952 households; kerosene was used by 104,399 households; charcoal was used by 32,675 households; and wood was used by 58,231 households; collectively accounting for 59 per cent of the households. There are about 73,000 P.U.B. consumers whose monthly bills range from $10 to $20. They will be liable to pay a levy of five per cent. Nearly half of these households will

Column: 794

have to pay between 50 cents and 70 cents per month and the other half will have to pay between 75 cents and $1 more per month. The small levy will not cause any hardship as these households are in the better financial position, or otherwise they would not be in a position to have fans, radios and refrigerators.

    The next category of households, numbering 32,000, have P.U.B. bills of between $21 and $30. They will be required to pay a levy of 10 per cent. These households will have to pay between $2 an $3 a month. Such households will normally have fans, television sets and refrigerators and the extra $2 to $3 a month is not likely to involve any sacrifice on their part.

    There are about 50,000 households with P.U.B. bills above $30. These households are the more affluent and they have refrigerators, television sets, water-heaters and even air-conditioners. These households also have two or three water closets. I am sure that these people can afford to pay a levy varying from $3 to $12 per month. Members will agree that the tax which rises from a few cents to a few dollars in line with the economic status of the households is not unreasonable.

    The levy on Singapore Telephone Board - for short, I shall just say S.T.B. - bills will only affect people with means, as the less well-to-do are unlikely to have a telephone. There are 45,104 residential lines and 35,552 business lines for our population of two million people. This is the first time for more than a decade that telephone subscribers will have to pay an additional amount, as the telephone charges have not been revised since 1958. Resisdential subscribers who do not make trunk calls frequently will, on the average, pay about $3.50 per line per month. I am sure the amount of tax is far from being exorbitant and can be borne easily.

    Although new administrative machinery is not requried for the collection of taxes on P.U.B. and S.T.B. bills, it is

Column: 795

necessary to provide by enactment of this Bill, legal authority for the imposition and collection of these taxes. The definition of "services" and "taxable services" in clause 2 of the Bill includes letting of apparatus or appliances.

    Clause 3 of the Bill empowers the Minister to specify by publishing an order in the Gazette the statutory boards and the services which will become taxable as well as the rates of tax to be charged.

    Clause 4 gives the power to the statutory board for the collection and recovery of this tax in such manner as approved by the Minister.

    Clause 5 stipulates that the tax collected under this Bill shall be paid into the Consolidated Fund.

    Clause 6 gives the power to the Minister to exempt any person from the payment of this tax. Under this provision, the Minister for Finance intends to exempt subscribers of the P.U.B, whose bills are below $10 per month and industrial consumers of electricity using more than 400,000 units of electricity a month.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Question put, and agreed to.

    Bill accordingly read a Second time and committed to a Committee of the whole House.

    The House immediately resolved itself into a Committee on the Bill. -[Mr Tang See Chim].

    Bill considered in Committee; reported without amendment; read a Third time and passed.

Column: 795

CUSTOMS (AMENDMENT) BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

3.05 p.m.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance (Mr Tang See Chim) (for the Minister for Finance): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

Column: 796



    The Bill before Parliament seeks to amend the Customs Ordinance, 1960 (No. 44 of 1960) to streamline customs procedures with a view to improving the efficiency of the Customs Department and reducing inconvenience to traders.

    I shall now deal with the important, amendments. Section 14 of the Ordinance is amended by the addition of a new section - section 14A - to allow for goods manufactured, assembled or produced in Singapore which are not subject to excise duties and which have been exported to be re-imported without payment of import duty. The importers will, however, have to satisfy the Comptroller of Customs that such goods have not undergone any processing or manipulation outside Singapore. At present, such exemptions are given on an ad hoc basis by the Minister. This causes some delay in clearance of goods and unnecessary correspondence.

    Under the existing Ordinance, drawback of duty is allowed on goods, subject to import duty, but not on goods, subject to excise duty. Clause 18 of the Bill extends drawback facilities to locally-manufactured products which may be subject to excise duty.

    At the moment, the power to levy or vary the special tax on diesel-engined vehicles lies with Parliament. Clause 6 is intended to transfer the power to the Minister. This will enable any changes to be made speedily by a Ministerial order.

    Clause 9 of the Bill simplifies the procedure for the duty-free importation of bona fide trade samples.

    Clause 11 of the Bill dispenses with the need for customs permits for dutiable imports except intoxicating liquors or tobacco where the duty is less than $100. This will expedite clearance of passengers.

    The other amendments are to raise the minimum amount from $10 to $100 for drawback claims and to reduce the period during which claims can be made from 12 months to six months, to give discretionary power to the Comptroller,

Column: 797

to waive collection of duty of less than $5, and to increase the maximum composition fee from $600 to $1,000 which is the level prevailing in Malaysia.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Question put, and agreed to.

    Bill accordingly read a Second time and committed to a Committee of the whole House.

    The House immediately resolved itself into a Committee on the Bill.- [Mr Tang See Chim].

    Bill considered in Committee; reported without amendment; read a Third Time and passed.

Column: 797

CINEMATOGRAPH FILM HIRE
DUTY (AMENDMENT) BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

3.13 p.m.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance (Mr Tang See Chim) (for the Minister for Finance): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    The Bill now before Parliament proposes two amendments to the Cinematograph Film Hire Duty Act, 1966. An amendment to section 10 to limit the amount of gross receipts which may be deducted by a film renter for the purposes of film hire duty assessment, and the other is an amendment to section 16 to enable senior officers of Customs to compound offences under the Act where the amount involved does not exceed $100.

    Film hire duty is assessed at 60 per cent of the gross receipts of a renter derived from the renting of films. For the purpose of duty assessment, a film renter is allowed to deduct from the gross receipts, proceeds derived from the sale or hire of advertising materials or accessories used in connection with the distribution or hire of films. There have been instances of renters deducting unreasonably large amounts in this respect, thus reducing the amount assessable for duty. As a remedy to such abuse, the amendment to section 10

Column: 798

of the Act limits such deductible amounts to 10 per cent of the gross receipts or $50, whichever is the lesser.

    At present, senior officers of Customs are empowered to conduct court prosecutions on behalf of the Comptroller of Customs and Excise for offences under the Act. Experience has shown that it is desirable to provide powers for such officers to compound offences involving sums of less than $100 to avoid taking cases to the court. This is effected by the proposed amendment to section 16 of the Act.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Question put, and agreed to.

    Bill accordingly read a Second time and committed to a Committee of the whole House.

    The House immediately resolved itself into a Committee on the Bill. -[Mr Tang See Chim].

    Bill considered in Committee; reported without amendment; read a Third time and passed.

Column: 798

DIPLOMATIC AND CONSULAR
OFFICERS (OATHS AND FEES) BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

3.18 p.m.

    The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Labour (Mr S. Rajaratnam): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    Singapore's international trading character, coupled with the fact that many of our citizens often travel to different parts of the world, makes it necessary that officers of our Diplomatic Corps should be enabled to administer oaths or affirmations, take affidavits and do notarial acts which notary publics in Singapore are normally empowered to undertake, and for these to be valid in law.

    From the copies of the Bill which have been provided, Members will have seen that the primary purpose of this Bill, as set out in clause 3, is to

Column: 799

empower diplomatic and consular officers of Singapore missions abroad, as well as those consular agents who may be acting for Singapore in countries where we are unrepresented, to perform these functions and levy appropriate fees for such services.

    Members will appreciate that the process of consolidating the friendly relations we have established with foreign countries will take time, money and personnel. Much as we would wish to do so, it will not be feasible to establish missions in every friendly country. As of today, we have diplomatic missions in 11 countries. In alphabetical order, our missions are located in Bangkok, Cairo, Canberra, Jakarta, Kuala Lumpur, London, New Delhi, Phnom Penh, Tokyo, Washington and Wellington. Besides these, we also have a Commissioner in Hong Kong and a permanent mission to the United Nations. With our citizens travelling and doing business with more countries than those in which we are represented, Singapore has to depend upon friendly governments with missions in those countries where we are unrepresented for the performance of the functions envisaged in the Bill as and when the need arises.

    As of today, Members will be interested to know, and note with appreciation the fact, that we have hitherto been assisted in this respect by the Governments of Malaysia, the United Kingdom and Thailand in different parts of the world where we have no missions of our own. Provision is, therefore, made in the Bill for such situations where these friendly governments can perform the functions envisaged in the Bill on our behalf and for these to be valid in law.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Question put, and agreed to.

    Bill accordingly read a Second time and committed to a Committee of the whole House.

    The House immediately resolved itself into a Committee on the Bill. -[Mr Rajaratnam].

Column: 800



    Bill considered in Committee; reported without amendment; read a Third time and passed.

Column: 800

SEAMEN'S REGISTRY BOARD
(AMENDMENT) BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

3.24 p.m.

    The Minister for Communications (Mr Yong Nyuk Lin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    There has been, in recent years, an increasing demand for Singapore seamen as a result of which the reserve pooi of seamen registered in the Seamen's Registry Board has fallen below the accepted minimum of 20 per cent.
